Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study a particular feature of walking and foot anatomy that may provide new insight about the evolution of bipedalism (walking upright) in humans. Humans and our closest living relatives, the African great apes, use a unique foot strike pattern in which they strike the ground with the heel first, before the rest of the foot (heel strike) when walking. Yet the factors influencing the evolution of a specialized foot posture and the first appearance of our unique (human) footfall patterns are still poorly understood. It is unknown to what degree heel strike is similar across humans and African apes, how it develops throughout an individual's lifetime, and how different patterns of heel strike are reflected in the anatomy of foot bones. This study tracks the development of foot posture in African apes and provides a unique opportunity to understand why African apes and humans heel strike, and to explore how fossil hominin foot bones might tell us about walking patterns during hominin evolution. This project will support an early career female scientist and provide numerous research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, with a specific focus on female and minority students. At the end of the project, all video and image data will be made available to other scientists and educators, and used to promote the research and education goals of public zoological facilities and sanctuaries. Information on heel strike can be applied not only to the fossil record but also to studies of foot development and injuries in humans.

The objective of this project is to quantify patterns of heel strike functional morphology throughout ontogeny in African hominoids. The study will quantify the range of variation in pedal mechanics and anatomy among living primates who use a heel strike through an experimental, comparative, ontogenetic approach, and ask: (1) are the mechanics of heel strike the same in all contexts in which it occurs?, (2) how do body size, behavior, age, and hind limb dynamics influence heel strike mechanics?, and (3) can heel strike be detected in external and internal calcaneal anatomy? To test hypotheses regarding the effect of hind limb mechanics on heel strike, kinematic data are analyzed from non-invasive video recordings of infant and adult chimpanzees and gorillas walking. To investigate how foot inversion and associated ground reaction forces that load the calcaneus change during locomotor development, the center of pressure and ground reaction forces incurred by the foot are recorded with a pressure mat mounted on top of a force platform. These data are compared with previously collected video data of wild chimpanzees. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and medical computed tomography (CT) are used to model how the African ape heel pad attenuates impact forces in the absence of a calcaneal lateral plantar process. These data are compared with microCT data of calcaneal trabecular architecture in captive and wild extant apes and humans and then applied to early fossil hominin calcanei (A. afarensis, and A. sediba). This integrative project is transformative because it investigates an entire functional chain: locomotor behavior and gait mechanics (kinematics, kinetics, and plantar pressure) throughout ontogeny, internal and external calcaneal structure in extant apes, and interpretation of fossil foot bone functional morphology. A comprehensive understanding of heel strike variation in living apes and its evolution in fossil hominins is an essential first step toward a broader understanding of the evolution of heel strike in hominoids.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, entitled Ontogeny of heel-strike in hominoids was funded by a grant from the National Science Foundation. The goal of this project was to test if the way that gorillas move their feet while walking changes as they age, and if so, how the shape of their foot (the heel pad and foot bones) reflect these changes in posture. Since we are closely related to gorillas, we used these data to understand gorilla and human anatomy.

To understand gorilla foot posture during walking, we worked with the North Carolina Zoo in Asheboro, North Carolina to design and build a runway for the gorillas to walk on. The runway is made out of a heavy plastic called starboard that is safe for the animals, easily cleaned, and can hold a 500-pound gorilla. The runway has cut outs in the main section to fit a force plate and pressure mat. These measure how much weight the gorillas put on their feet and where on the feet the load is highest. We collected simultaneous video, force, and pressure data for gorillas of many ages so that we could match their foot posture with the loads they experience. This is the first-time data like these have been collected on gorillas. We also looked at the anatomy of their limbs and the fat pad at their heel.

Overall, we found that many features of gorilla walking differ from those of other primates (lemurs, monkeys, apes, and, of course, humans). First, we found that gorillas use a walking trot in which the right backfoot and the left forefoot move and land together. This is rare for primates. Occurrence of trotting changes with age, with older animals trotting all the. We also found that even young gorillas (6 months old) use a human-like foot posture in which the heel touches the ground first at the beginning of a step (heel strike). Chimpanzees develop this pattern later in life. At heel strike, gorillas (like humans) experience a lot of pressure and very high forces under their heel called an impact spike as they forcefully and rapidly apply their heel to the ground. They have an expansive fat pad at their heel (bigger even than our own) that appears to absorb these loads and distribute the pressure. Gorillas also move their hips and knees in a way that is different from other apes like chimpanzees but similar to humans. Like other primates, gorillas put more weight on their feet than they do on their hands. But this also changes with age, with older gorillas shifting to a more even distribution of load between the hands and feet. This pattern relating to age has never been recorded before. Overall, we found that gorilla behavior changes with age.  Although there are some similarities among all of the great apes, gorillas are also different in ways that may help us understand our own special way of walking.

This project offered training and hands-on research experience for multiple students at various points in their career. We trained an undergraduate student and a high school student to code foot postures at heel strike and to digitize (identify joints in video images and convert those to x,y coordinates to calculate angles) joint centers of rotation for the hind limb in each video. We also trained two local high school students and a recent Duke graduate to calculate spatiotemporal variables (timing of hand and foot contacts) such as foot contact time, duty factor (contact time as a percentage of stride duration), and step length for each video. We trained an undergraduate student in dissection of human heel pads at the Duke School of Medicine. This student then designed and completed his own senior honors thesis project. We worked with another undergraduate student on his senior honors thesis that examined muscle fiber types in the hindlimbs of chimpanzees and gorillas. He presented his preliminary results as a poster at a conference and we are working with him to prepare two manuscripts for publication. In addition, this project has provided educational outreach for the NC Zoo. Visitors could observe our setup and data collection and when possible, we came to the front area and discussed our project. We presented talks at the NC Zoo for their staff and for a high school class. We also participated in outreach events at the zoo and brought standard and 3D printed models of gorilla bones to present to children and adults outside the exhibit area.
